37|27|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And some of them draw near unto others, mutually questioning. 
37|28|as-Saffat: The Rangers|They say: Lo! ye used to come unto us, imposing, (swearing that ye spoke  the truth). 
37|29|as-Saffat: The Rangers|They answer: Nay, but ye (yourselves) were not believers. 
37|30|as-Saffat: The Rangers|We had no power over you, but ye were wayward folk. 
37|31|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Now the Word of our Lord hath been fulfilled concerning us. Lo! we are  about to taste (the doom). 
37|32|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Thus we misled you. Lo! we were (ourselves) astray. 
37|33|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Then lo! this day they (both) are sharers in the doom. 
37|34|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Lo! thus deal We with the guilty. 
37|35|as-Saffat: The Rangers|For when it was said unto them, There is no God save Allah, they were  scornful 
37|36|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And said: Shall we forsake our gods for a mad poet ? 
37|37|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Nay, but he brought the Truth, and he confirmed those sent (before him). 
37|38|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Lo! (now) verily ye taste the painful doom - 
37|39|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Ye are requited naught save what ye did - 
37|40|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Save single-minded slaves of Allah; 
37|41|as-Saffat: The Rangers|For them there is a known provision, 
37|42|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Fruits. And they will be honoured 
37|43|as-Saffat: The Rangers|In the Gardens of delight, 
37|44|as-Saffat: The Rangers|On couches facing one another; 
37|45|as-Saffat: The Rangers|A cup from a gushing spring is brought round for them, 
37|46|as-Saffat: The Rangers|White, delicious to the drinkers, 
37|47|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Wherein there is no headache nor are they made mad thereby. 
37|48|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And with them are those of modest gaze, with lovely eyes, 
37|49|as-Saffat: The Rangers|(Pure) as they were hidden eggs (of the ostrich). 
37|50|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And some of them draw near unto others, mutually questioning. 
37|51|as-Saffat: The Rangers|A speaker of them saith: Lo! I had a comrade 
37|52|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Who used to say: Art thou in truth of those who put faith (in his words) ? 
37|53|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Can we, when we are dead and have become mere dust and bones - can we  (then) verily be brought to book ? 
37|54|as-Saffat: The Rangers|He saith: Will ye look ? 
37|55|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Then looketh he and seeth him in the depth of hell. 
37|56|as-Saffat: The Rangers|He saith: By Allah, thou verily didst all but cause my ruin, 
37|57|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And had it not been for the favour of my Lord, I too had been of those haled  forth (to doom). 
37|58|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Are we then not to die 
37|59|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Saving our former death, and are we not to be punished ? 
37|60|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Lo! this is the supreme triumph. 
37|61|as-Saffat: The Rangers|For the like of this, then, let the workers work. 
37|62|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Is this better as a welcome, or the tree of Zaqqum ? 
37|63|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Lo! We have appointed it a torment for wrong-doers. 
37|64|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Lo! it is a tree that springeth in the heart of hell. 
37|65|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Its crop is as it were the heads of devils

37|67|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And afterward, lo! thereupon they have a drink of boiling water 
37|68|as-Saffat: The Rangers|And afterward, lo! their return is surely unto hell. 
37|69|as-Saffat: The Rangers|They indeed found their fathers astray,

37|73|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Then see the nature of the consequence for those warned, 
37|74|as-Saffat: The Rangers|Save single-minded slaves of Allah.

38|1|Sad: Sad|Sad. By the renowned Qur'an, 
38|2|Sad: Sad|Nay, but those who disbelieve are in false pride and schism. 
38|3|Sad: Sad|How many a generation We destroyed before them, and they cried out when  it was no longer the time for escape! 
38|4|Sad: Sad|And they marvel that a warner from among themselves hath come unto them,  and the disbelievers say: This is a wizard, a charlatan. 
38|5|Sad: Sad|Maketh he the gods One God ? Lo! that is an astounding thing. 
38|6|Sad: Sad|The chiefs among them go about, exhorting: Go and be staunch to your gods!  Lo! this is a thing designed. 
38|7|Sad: Sad|We have not heard of this in later religion. This is naught but an invention. 
38|8|Sad: Sad|Hath the reminder been unto him (alone) among us ? Nay, but they are in  doubt concerning My reminder; nay but they have not yet tasted My doom. 
38|9|Sad: Sad|Or are theirs the treasures of the mercy of thy Lord, the Mighty, the  Bestower ? 
38|10|Sad: Sad|Or is the kingdom of the heavens and the earth and all that is between them  theirs ? Then let them ascend by ropes! 
38|11|Sad: Sad|A defeated host are (all) the factions that are there. 
38|12|Sad: Sad|The folk of Noah before them denied (their messenger) and (so did the tribe  of) A'ad, and Pharaoh firmly planted, 
38|13|Sad: Sad|And (the tribe of) Thamud, and the folk of Lot, and the dwellers in the wood:  these were the factions. 
38|14|Sad: Sad|Not one of them but did deny the messengers, therefor My doom was  justified, 
38|15|Sad: Sad|These wait for but one Shout, there will be no second thereto. 
38|16|Sad: Sad|They say: Our Lord! Hasten on for us our fate before the Day of Reckoning. 
38|17|Sad: Sad|Bear with what they say, and remember Our bondman David, lord of might,  Lo! he was ever turning in repentance (toward Allah). 
38|18|Sad: Sad|Lo! We subdued the hills to hymn the praises (of their Lord) with him at  nightfall and sunrise, 
38|19|Sad: Sad|And the birds assembled; all were turning unto Him. 
38|20|Sad: Sad|We made his kingdom strong and gave him wisdom and decisive speech. 
38|21|Sad: Sad|And hath the story of the litigants come unto thee ? How they climbed the  wall into the royal chamber; 
38|22|Sad: Sad|How they burst in upon David, and he was afraid of them. They said: Be not  afraid! (We are) two litigants, one of whom hath wronged the other, therefor judge  aright between us; be not unjust; and show us the fair way. 
38|23|Sad: Sad|Lo! this my brother hath ninety and nine ewes while I had one ewe; and he  said: Entrust it to me, and he conquered me in speech. 
38|24|Sad: Sad|(David) said: He hath wronged thee in demanding thine ewe in addition to  his ewes, and lo! many partners oppress one another, save such as believe and do  good works, and they are few. And David guessed that We had tried him, and he  sought forgiveness of his Lord, and he bowed himself and fell down prostrate and  repented. 
38|25|Sad: Sad|So We forgave him that; and lo! he had access to Our presence and a happy  journey's end. 
38|26|Sad: Sad|(And it was said unto him): O David! Lo! We have set thee as a viceroy in  the earth; therefor judge aright between mankind, and follow not desire that it beguile  thee from the way of Allah. Lo! those who wander from the way of Allah have an  awful doom, forasmuch as they forgot the Day of Reckoning. 
38|27|Sad: Sad|And We created not the heaven and the earth and all that is between them in  vain. That is the opinion of those who disbelieve. And woe unto those who disbelieve,  from the Fire! 
38|28|Sad: Sad|Shall We treat those who believe and do good works as those who spread  corruption in the earth; or shall We treat the pious as the wicked ? 
38|29|Sad: Sad|(This is) a Scripture that We have revealed unto thee, full of blessing, that  they may ponder its revelations, and that men of understanding may reflect. 
38|30|Sad: Sad|And We bestowed on David, Solomon. How excellent a slave! Lo! he was  ever turning in repentance (toward Allah). 
38|31|Sad: Sad|When there were shown to him at eventide lightfooted coursers 
38|32|Sad: Sad|And he said: Lo! I have preferred the good things (of the world) to the  remembrance of my Lord; till they were taken out of sight behind the curtain. 
38|33|Sad: Sad|(Then he said): Bring them back to me, and fell to slashing (with his sword  their) legs and necks. 
38|34|Sad: Sad|And verily We tried Solomon, and set upon his throne a (mere) body. Then  did he repent. 
38|35|Sad: Sad|He said: My Lord! Forgive me and bestow on me sovereignty such as shall  not belong to any after me. Lo! Thou art the Bestower. 
38|36|Sad: Sad|So We made the wind subservient unto him, setting fair by his command  whithersoever he intended. 
38|37|Sad: Sad|And the unruly, every builder and diver (made We subservient), 
38|38|Sad: Sad|And others linked together in chains, 
38|39|Sad: Sad|(Saying): This is Our gift, so bestow thou, or withhold, without reckoning. 
38|40|Sad: Sad|And lo! he hath favour with Us, and a happy journey's end. 
38|41|Sad: Sad|And make mention (O Muhammad) of Our bondman Job, when he cried unto  his Lord (saying): Lo! the devil doth afflict me with distress and torment. 
38|42|Sad: Sad|(And it was said unto him): Strike the ground with thy foot. This (spring) is a  cool bath and a refreshing drink. 
38|43|Sad: Sad|And We bestowed on him (again) his household and therewith the like  thereof, a mercy from Us, and a memorial for men of understanding. 
38|44|Sad: Sad|And (it was said unto him): Take in thine hand a branch and smite therewith,  and break not thine oath. Lo! We found him steadfast, how excellent a slave! Lo! he  was ever turning in repentance (to his Lord). 
38|45|Sad: Sad|And make mention of Our bondmen, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, men of parts  and vision. 
38|46|Sad: Sad|Lo! We purified them with a pure thought, remembrance of the Home (of the  Hereafter). 
38|47|Sad: Sad|Lo! in Our sight they are verily of the elect, the excellent. 
38|48|Sad: Sad|And make mention of Ishmael and Elisha and Dhu'l-Kifl. All are of the  chosen. 
38|49|Sad: Sad|This is a reminder. And lo! for those who ward off (evil) is a happy journey's  end, 
38|50|Sad: Sad|Gardens of Eden, whereof the gates are opened for them,

38|53|Sad: Sad|This it is that ye are promised for the Day of Reckoning. 
38|54|Sad: Sad|Lo! this in truth is Our provision, which will never waste away. 
38|55|Sad: Sad|This (is for the righteous). And lo! for the transgressors there with be an evil  journey's end, 
38|56|Sad: Sad|Hell, where they will burn, an evil resting-place. 
38|57|Sad: Sad|Here is a boiling and an ice-cold draught, so let them taste it, 
38|58|Sad: Sad|And other (torment) of the kind in pairs (the two extremes)! 
38|59|Sad: Sad|Here is an army rushing blindly with you. (Those who are already in the Fire  say): No word of welcome for them. Lo! they will roast at the Fire. 
38|60|Sad: Sad|They say: Nay, but you (misleaders), for you there is no word of welcome.  Ye prepared this for us (by your misleading). Now hapless is the plight.
